Heh. Just playing with this as an inital test of sharpneat 2's
hyperneat support. It takes a while to solve, and so, I provided a
substrate connection length input to the CPPN as explained in the
relevant paper. Result? Problem solved perfectly by one of the initial
genomes!

I have to say that this isn't entirely unexpected, I figured it was
going to be a much simpler task.

This leads me back to a thought that's been rattling around my head
for some years now, which is that although traditional ANNs with
sigmoid activation function /can/ approximate any function, in reality
they're pretty bad at comparison and multiplication - the two major
operations required to calculate length (euclidean distance between
two points).

Of course none of this invalidates the observation that hyperneat
handles large arrays of geometrically arranged input and output nodes
far better than NEAT. On the contrary, it very much reinforces that
notion.

Colin.
